page.title: 17The Valley Floor
page.content: The flood plain of the river Ouse is just over half a kilometre wide and it runs south between steeply sloping hills both east and west. As recently as 1900 the whole valley floor (known locally as 'the brooks') was covered by water meadows and were flooded for most of the winter months. A network of drains now keeps the fields dry, but almost all are still pasture (flood plain soils are generally fertile alluvium, but there is much coarse gravel and heavy clay here too.) The river Ouse is in a course that swings from one side of the flood-plain to the other between high man-made banks or levees of crushed chalk. The valley is a narrow routeway, with two roads, a railway and a double line of electricity pylons all within half a kilometre of Deans Farm.
